material.mattext: Please solve the following exercises.
##AssessmentFeedback##
Please answer the following question.

A scientist is investigating whether a chemical may effect the growth of an organism. Under the control conditions (no chemical), the organism grows to a mean mass of μ0=25\mu_0 = 25 grams with a standard deviation of σ0=7.2\sigma_0 =7.2 grams. These population parameters are known precisely because the organism has been grown under control conditions many many times.

The scientist has only grown the organism under experimental conditions (with chemical) n=97n=97 times. In that sample, the masses have a mean x‾=26.26\bar{x}=26.26.

The scientist wonders if this sample mean is significantly different from μ0\mu_0. To investigate this, the scientist will determine the pp-value. The pp-value represents the probability of getting a sample mean as far (or farther) from μ0\mu_0 due to chance alone.

It is common to compare the pp-value to 0.05.

  • If p-value<0.05p\text{-value} < 0.05 then the difference of means is “significant” and warrants publication.
  • If p-value≥0.05p\text{-value} \ge 0.05 then “not significant”. It is possible a larger sample size will allow detection of a significant difference, or maybe the chemical has no effect.

p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)p\text{-value} ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right)

Determine the pp-value.

video

First, calculate the zz-score. Then use chadworley.github.io/sn.html to determine P(|Z|>|z-score|)P(|Z|>|z\text{-score}|). p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)=P(|Z|>|26.26−25|7.2/97)=P(|Z|>1.7235501)=0.0847891\begin{aligned} p\text{-value} &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|26.26-25\big|}{7.2/\sqrt{97}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > 1.7235501 \right) \\\\ &= 0.0847891 \end{aligned}

Of course you could have rounded the zz score. Either of the following will also get credit.

p-value=(|Z|>1.72)=0.0854p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.72 \right) ~=~ 0.0854 p-value=(|Z|>1.73)=0.0836p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.73 \right) ~=~ 0.0836

The difference is not significant; we don’t know whether the chemical alters the growth of the organism.

video

Of course you could have rounded the zz score. Either of the following will also get credit.

p-value=(|Z|>1.72)=0.0854p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.72 \right) ~=~ 0.0854 p-value=(|Z|>1.73)=0.0836p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.73 \right) ~=~ 0.0836

The difference is not significant; we don’t know whether the chemical alters the growth of the organism.

Determine the pp-value.

video

First, calculate the zz-score. Then use chadworley.github.io/sn.html to determine P(|Z|>|z-score|)P(|Z|>|z\text{-score}|). p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)=P(|Z|>|68.75−74.4|14.3/41)=P(|Z|>2.5299057)=0.0114093\begin{aligned} p\text{-value} &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|68.75-74.4\big|}{14.3/\sqrt{41}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > 2.5299057 \right) \\\\ &= 0.0114093 \end{aligned}

Of course you could have rounded the zz score. Either of the following will also get credit.

p-value=(|Z|>2.53)=0.0114p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 2.53 \right) ~=~ 0.0114 p-value=(|Z|>2.52)=0.0118p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 2.52 \right) ~=~ 0.0118

The difference is significant; the chemical seems to alter the growth of the organism.

  • If p-value≥0.05p\text{-value} \ge 0.05 then “not significant”. It is possible a larger sample size will allow detection of a significant difference, or maybe the chemical has no effect.

p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)p\text{-value} ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right)

Determine the pp-value.

video

First, calculate the zz-score. Then use chadworley.github.io/sn.html to determine P(|Z|>|z-score|)P(|Z|>|z\text{-score}|). p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)=P(|Z|>|69.06−72.4|17.1/84)=P(|Z|>1.7901524)=0.0734294\begin{aligned} p\text{-value} &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|69.06-72.4\big|}{17.1/\sqrt{84}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > 1.7901524 \right) \\\\ &= 0.0734294 \end{aligned}

Of course you could have rounded the zz score. Either of the following will also get credit.

p-value=(|Z|>1.8)=0.0718p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.8 \right) ~=~ 0.0718 p-value=(|Z|>1.79)=0.0734p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.79 \right) ~=~ 0.0734

A scientist is investigating whether a chemical may effect the growth of an organism. Under the control conditions (no chemical), the organism grows to a mean mass of μ0=71.7\mu_0 = 71.7 grams with a standard deviation of σ0=15.9\sigma_0 =15.9 grams. These population parameters are known precisely because the organism has been grown under control conditions many many times.

The scientist has only grown the organism under experimental conditions (with chemical) n=28n=28 times. In that sample, the masses have a mean x‾=66.41\bar{x}=66.41.

The scientist wonders if this sample mean is significantly different from μ0\mu_0. To investigate this, the scientist will determine the pp-value. The pp-value represents the probability of getting a sample mean as far (or farther) from μ0\mu_0 due to chance alone.

It is common to compare the pp-value to 0.05.

  • If p-value<0.05p\text{-value} < 0.05 then the difference of means is “significant” and warrants publication.
  • If p-value≥0.05p\text{-value} \ge 0.05 then “not significant”. It is possible a larger sample size will allow detection of a significant difference, or maybe the chemical has no effect.

p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)p\text{-value} ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right)

Of course you could have rounded the zz score. Either of the following will also get credit.

p-value=(|Z|>1.77)=0.0768p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.77 \right) ~=~ 0.0768 p-value=(|Z|>1.76)=0.0784p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.76 \right) ~=~ 0.0784

A scientist is investigating whether a chemical may effect the growth of an organism. Under the control conditions (no chemical), the organism grows to a mean mass of μ0=16.3\mu_0 = 16.3 grams with a standard deviation of σ0=4.9\sigma_0 =4.9 grams. These population parameters are known precisely because the organism has been grown under control conditions many many times.

The scientist has only grown the organism under experimental conditions (with chemical) n=49n=49 times. In that sample, the masses have a mean x‾=14.98\bar{x}=14.98.

The scientist wonders if this sample mean is significantly different from μ0\mu_0. To investigate this, the scientist will determine the pp-value. The pp-value represents the probability of getting a sample mean as far (or farther) from μ0\mu_0 due to chance alone.

It is common to compare the pp-value to 0.05.

  • If p-value<0.05p\text{-value} < 0.05 then the difference of means is “significant” and warrants publication.
  • If p-value≥0.05p\text{-value} \ge 0.05 then “not significant”. It is possible a larger sample size will allow detection of a significant difference, or maybe the chemical has no effect.

p-value=(|Z|>2.44)=0.0146p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 2.44 \right) ~=~ 0.0146 p-value=(|Z|>2.45)=0.0142p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 2.45 \right) ~=~ 0.0142

The difference is significant; the chemical seems to alter the growth of the organism.

A scientist is investigating whether a chemical may effect the growth of an organism. Under the control conditions (no chemical), the organism grows to a mean mass of μ0=40.8\mu_0 = 40.8 grams with a standard deviation of σ0=12.3\sigma_0 =12.3 grams. These population parameters are known precisely because the organism has been grown under control conditions many many times.

The scientist has only grown the organism under experimental conditions (with chemical) n=51n=51 times. In that sample, the masses have a mean x‾=37.85\bar{x}=37.85.

The scientist wonders if this sample mean is significantly different from μ0\mu_0. To investigate this, the scientist will determine the pp-value. The pp-value represents the probability of getting a sample mean as far (or farther) from μ0\mu_0 due to chance alone.

It is common to compare the pp-value to 0.05.

  • If p-value<0.05p\text{-value} < 0.05 then the difference of means is “significant” and warrants publication.
  • If p-value≥0.05p\text{-value} \ge 0.05 then “not significant”. It is possible a larger sample size will allow detection of a significant difference, or maybe the chemical has no effect.

p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)p\text{-value} ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right)

Determine the pp-value.

video

First, calculate the zz-score. Then use chadworley.github.io/sn.html to determine P(|Z|>|z-score|)P(|Z|>|z\text{-score}|). p-value=P(|Z|>|x‾−μ0|σ0/n)=P(|Z|>|37.85−40.8|12.3/51)=P(|Z|>1.7127816)=0.0867527\begin{aligned} p\text{-value} &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|\bar{x}-\mu_0\big|}{\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{\big|37.85-40.8\big|}{12.3/\sqrt{51}} \right) \\\\ &= P\left(\big|Z\big| > 1.7127816 \right) \\\\ &= 0.0867527 \end{aligned}

Of course you could have rounded the zz score. Either of the following will also get credit.

p-value=(|Z|>1.72)=0.0854p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.72 \right) ~=~ 0.0854 p-value=(|Z|>1.71)=0.0872p\text{-value} ~=~ \left(\big|Z\big| > 1.71 \right) ~=~ 0.0872

The difference is not significant; we don’t know whether the chemical alters the growth of the organism.
